com.strongloop.android.remoting.adapters

Class Adapter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.strongloop.android.remoting.adapters.Adapter
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    RestAdapter

    public abstract class Adapter
extends java.lang.Object
    The entry point to all networking accomplished with LoopBack. Adapters encapsulate information consistent to all networked operations, such as base URL, port, etc.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  Adapter.BinaryCallback
      A callback receiving the HTTP response body in the binary form.
      static interface  Adapter.Callback
      A callback that returns the HTTP response body.
      static class  Adapter.JsonArrayCallback
      A callback that returns a JSON array.
      static class  Adapter.JsonCallback
      A callback that parses a JSON response.
      static class  Adapter.JsonObjectCallback
      A callback that returns a JSON object.

      Creates a new, disconnected Adapter.

      • isConnected

        public abstract boolean isConnected()
        Gets whether this adapter is connected to a server.
        Returns:
        true if connected, false otherwise.

      • invokeStaticMethod

        public abstract void invokeStaticMethod(java.lang.String method,
                      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> parameters,
                      Adapter.Callback callback)
        Invokes a remotable method exposed statically on the server.

        Unlike invokeInstanceMethod(String, Map, Map, Callback), no object needs to be created on the server.

        Parameters:
        method - The method to invoke, e.g. "module.doSomething".
        parameters - The parameters to invoke with.
        callback - The callback to invoke when the execution finishes.

      • invokeStaticMethod

        public void invokeStaticMethod(java.lang.String method,
                      java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> parameters,
                      Adapter.BinaryCallback callback)
        Invokes a remotable method exposed statically on the server, parses the response as binary data.

        Unlike invokeInstanceMethod(String, Map, Map, BinaryCallback), no object needs to be created on the server.

        Parameters:
        method - The method to invoke, e.g. "module.doSomething".
        parameters - The parameters to invoke with.
        callback - The callback to invoke when the execution finishes.

      • invokeInstanceMethod

        public abstract void invokeInstanceMethod(java.lang.String method,
                        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> constructorParameters,
                        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> parameters,
                        Adapter.Callback callback)
        Invokes a remotable method exposed within a prototype on the server.

        This should be thought of as a two-step process. First, the server loads or creates an object with the appropriate type. Then and only then is the method invoked on that object. The two parameter dictionaries correspond to these two steps: `creationParameters` for the former, and `parameters` for the latter.

        Parameters:
        method - The method to invoke, e.g. "MyClass.prototype.doSomething".
        constructorParameters - The parameters the virtual object should be created with.
        parameters - The parameters to invoke with.
        callback - The callback to invoke when the execution finishes.

      • invokeInstanceMethod

        public void invokeInstanceMethod(java.lang.String method,
                        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> constructorParameters,
                        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,? extends java.lang.Object> parameters,
                        Adapter.BinaryCallback callback)
        Invokes a remotable method exposed within a prototype on the server, parses the response as binary data.

        This should be thought of as a two-step process. First, the server loads or creates an object with the appropriate type. Then and only then is the method invoked on that object. The two parameter dictionaries correspond to these two steps: `creationParameters` for the former, and `parameters` for the latter.

        Parameters:
        method - The method to invoke, e.g. "MyClass.prototype.doSomething".
        constructorParameters - The parameters the virtual object should be created with.
        parameters - The parameters to invoke with.
        callback - The callback to invoke when the execution finishes.
